item.content:encoded:
Protein plays a central role in building and repairing muscle, supporting metabolic health, and maintaining strength as we age. Whether you’re active, managing body composition goals, or simply trying to meet daily nutritional needs, the right protein supplement can help you reach optimal intake—supported by strong scientific evidence.

This guide breaks down the major protein types, how they work in your body, and which formats best match your lifestyle and goals.

For a deeper look at why protein matters and how supplementation supports muscle, metabolism, and healthy aging, see our companion guide: Protein Supplements: What They Are and Why They Matter. 

Protein Quality: What Makes One “Better” Than Another

Not all proteins stimulate muscle growth equally. Three factors matter most:

Essential Amino Acid (EAA) content: These cannot be produced by the body and must come from food. Proteins rich in EAAs produce a stronger muscle-building response.

Leucine content: Leucine is the amino acid that “flips the switch” on muscle protein synthesis (MPS). Higher leucine means a faster, stronger anabolic signal. Whey is the richest common source.

Digestibility and Bioavailability: How much of the protein your body actually absorbs and uses matters. Scientists measure this with a score called DIAAS, where higher is better.

Comparing Protein Types

Whey Protein (Isolate, Concentrate, Hydrolysate)

Best for: post-workout recovery, muscle building, older adults, high-leucine needs

Whey is the most researched protein supplement, with decades of evidence supporting its effectiveness. It digests quickly, creates a rapid rise in blood amino acids, and is exceptionally high in leucine.

Whey Protein Isolate (WPI)

  • The most refined form with ≥ 90% protein
  • Low in lactose
  • Fastest absorption, allowing for a large amino acid spike
  • Extremely high leucine (AARR ~2.57)
  • Excellent for post-workout or morning use

Whey Protein Concentrate (WPC)

  • Less processed, can contain 25–89% protein
  • Contains some beneficial milk peptides
  • More affordable but less refined and includes more lactose and fat

Whey Hydrolysate (WPH)

  • Pre-digested for even faster absorption
  • Shown to stimulate MPS more than casein or soy
  • Typically higher-cost

Casein Protein

Best for: overnight recovery, sustained satiety, long fasting windows

  • Slow-digesting: releases amino acids for 6+ hours
  • Ideal before sleep or during long gaps between meals
  • Improves nitrogen retention
  • Supports long-term muscle maintenance and reduces breakdown overnight.

Plant Proteins (Soy, Pea, Rice, Blends)

Best for: vegans, vegetarians, dairy-free diets, those with dairy allergies

Plant proteins vary widely in quality. None match whey for leucine content or digestibility, but they’re effective options for those avoiding animal products.

Soy Protein Isolate (SPI)

  • The most complete plant protein
  • DIAAS ~0.90
  • Well researched and effective but produces lower MPS response vs whey at equal doses

Pea Protein

  • DIAAS ~0.82
  • Popular with dairy-free users
  • Good amino acid profile but typically low in methionine

Rice Protein

  • DIAAS ~0.37
  • Incomplete on its own (low in lysine)
  • Rarely used alone

Plant Blends

  • Combined sources ( pea + rice + other) creates a more complete amino acid profile. This is the best approach for plant-based users.
  • Still produce 30–40% lower circulating amino acids compared to whey
  • Best used when avoiding animal proteins, not for maximizing MPS

Novel & Specialty Proteins

Collagen

Collagen has legitimate benefits: research supports its use for skin hydration, joint comfort, and gut health. However, it’s not a complete protein and lacks the amino acids needed to effectively stimulate muscle growth. If your goal is building or maintaining muscle, collagen shouldn’t be your primary protein source. Think of it as a complement, not a replacement.

Egg Protein

  • Complete, highly digestible, and has a long history of use
  • Less modern research compared to whey, but the amino acid profile is strong
  • Good alternative for dairy-sensitive individuals who want high-quality animal protein

Which Protein Is Best for You? (SiPhox Recommendations)

Goal Best Choice Why
Maximize muscle growth or post-workout recovery Whey Isolate or Hydrolysate Fastest absorption, richest in leucine
Healthy aging / preventing muscle loss Whey Isolate + spread across 3–4 meals Strongest MPS stimulation per dose
Overnight recovery / reducing muscle breakdown Casein Slow release of essential amino acids
Weight management / satiety Casein or Whey Isolate Both support fullness; casein lasts longer
Vegan or dairy-free users Plant Protein Blend More complete amino acid profile
Skin & joint support Collagen Not for MPS; beneficial for connective tissue

Formats: Powder vs. Shakes vs. Bars

Protein Powders

  • The most versatile and cost-effective option
  • Highest protein purity
  • Easy to dose control (20–40 g servings)
  • Best option for daily or post-workout use

Ready-to-Drink (RTD) Shakes

  • Convenient and portable when traveling or short on time
  • More expensive per gram of protein
  • May contain added sugars, oils or stabilizers

Protein Bars

  • Great for on-the-go or meal replacement
  • Typically higher calorie, carb and fat content
  • Not ideal for rapid post-exercise MPS, but useful for sustained energy

How to Use Protein for Best Results

Daily Target: Most people benefit from 1.0–1.6 g/kg per day, depending on activity and age.

Per-Meal Target

  • Young adults: ~0.4 g/kg/meal
  • Adults 60+: ~0.6 g/kg/meal
  • Aim for 3–4 protein-rich meals per day. This maximizes muscle protein synthesis throughout the day.

Timing Recommendations

  • Post-workout → Whey isolate (fast absorption when muscles are primed)
  • Before bed → Casein (sustained release overnight)
  • Between meals → Whey, plant blend, or a protein bar

A Note on Safety

Protein supplementation is considered safe for healthy individuals. Research shows no negative effects on kidney function or bone density at the intake levels discussed here. However:

  • Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD) should follow clinician-directed intake (usually lower at 0.3–0.9 g/kg/day).
  • Everyone should ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D to support bone health when consuming high protein diets.

Key Takeaway

Protein supplements are a powerful tool for supporting muscle health, metabolism, recovery, and healthy aging. The “best” protein depends on your goals, dietary restrictions, and preferences. While many options exist, high-quality whey proteins—especially isolates—deliver the strongest, most consistent results across scientific studies. Plant proteins provide valuable alternatives for those avoiding dairy, though they may require higher doses to match anabolic signaling.

Choose your format based on your needs:

  • Best for overall results: Whey Isolate
  • Best for sustained release: Casein
  • Best plant-based option: Plant protein blend
  • Best convenience: RTD shake
  • Best portability: Protein bar

Supporting optimal protein intake is one of the most impactful, and most science-backed, nutrition strategies for improving long-term health.

item.content:encoded:
Creatine is one of the most well-studied and effective supplements on the market. Its popularity among athletes spans decades, backed by hundreds of studies proving its effectiveness. Recent research has expanded beyond athletic performance, showing promising results for cognitive function, healthy aging, and bone health.

However, with countless creatine products available—each claiming superiority—choosing the right supplement can feel overwhelming. This guide breaks down the different types of creatine and delivery formats so you can make an informed decision about which supplement is best for you.

Comparing Types of Creatine

The market offers numerous forms of creatine, from tried-and-true classics to newer, more novel variants. Each type often claims superiority in stability, bioavailability, or performance enhancement. Here’s what the science actually says.

Creatine Monohydrate (CrM): The Gold Standard

Creatine monohydrate is considered the “gold standard” of creatine supplements—and for good reason.

Why It’s Superior:

  • Most researched: Nearly all creatine studies use CrM, with hundreds of peer-reviewed papers confirming its efficacy and safety
  • Excellent absorption: Research shows that 99% of CrM is either absorbed into muscle tissue or excreted through urine
  • Well-established safety profile: Decades of use with consistent safety data
  • Most cost-effective: Typically cheaper than alternative forms

Bottom Line: If you want the most scientifically validated and affordable option, creatine monohydrate is your best choice.

Creatine Hydrochloride (HCL): Better Solubility, Same Results

Creatine HCL is a creatine molecule bonded with a hydrochloride salt, which gives it superior solubility compared to CrM.

The Reality:

  • Better texture: Dissolves more easily, creating a smoother drink
  • No absorption advantage: Despite marketing claims, research shows Cr-HCL is not more effective than CrM at lower or standard doses
  • Higher cost: More expensive than CrM without additional benefits

Bottom Line: If grittiness bothers you and you don’t mind paying more for a smoother texture, Cr-HCL is fine—but it offers no performance advantage over monohydrate.

Buffered Creatine: A Solution to a Non-Existent Problem

Buffered creatine is marketed as “pH-correct” creatine that supposedly prevents breakdown into creatinine in stomach acid, leading to better muscle uptake at lower doses.

The Reality:

  • Unnecessary: CrM is already very stable during digestion and has excellent absorption
  • No added benefit: When compared head-to-head at the same dose, buffered creatine showed no advantages over CrM
  • Higher cost: More expensive without proven benefits

Bottom Line: Save your money. CrM already works exceptionally well without pH buffering.

Creatine Nitrate (CrN) and Other Novel Forms

Creatine nitrate bonds creatine to a nitrate ion, which may improve solubility and potentially offer vascular benefits from the nitrate component.

The Reality:

  • Good, but not better: CrN can be an effective creatine source, but offers no bioavailability advantage over CrM
  • Limited research: Most alternative creatine forms lack peer-reviewed evidence supporting superiority claims
  • Higher cost: Typically more expensive than CrM

Bottom Line: Novel forms sound impressive, but decades of research consistently show that creatine monohydrate remains the most effective and economical choice.

Key Takeaway: Stick with Creatine Monohydrate

With hundreds of peer-reviewed studies spanning several decades, creatine monohydrate is the best creatine supplement on the market. Alternative forms have not been proven to provide greater benefits and are almost always more expensive. Don’t fall for marketing hype—choose the supplement backed by science.

Powder vs. Pills vs. Gummies: Which Format Is Right for You?

Once you’ve decided on creatine monohydrate, you’ll need to choose a delivery format. Here’s how they compare:

1. Creatine Powder: The Proven Performer

Creatine powder (typically CrM) is the most extensively studied and effective format.

Category Details
Efficacy & Evidence Decades of research confirm powder’s ability to increase muscle creatine stores. It’s the preferred choice if you value robust scientific evidence.
Dosing Flexibility Highly flexible and precise. Easy to measure exact doses (3-5 grams per day or 0.1 gram per kilogram of body weight) and adjust as needed.
Cost Most affordable option due to simpler manufacturing. Best value for money.
Mixability/Taste Requires measuring and mixing with liquids (water, juice, or shakes). Standard forms may leave a gritty residue if not mixed thoroughly. Unflavored powder has minimal taste.
Absorption Dissolves in liquids, facilitating fast absorption.
Side Effects May cause gastrointestinal discomfort or bloating if not properly dissolved or taken in large doses. Splitting larger doses into multiple smaller servings can help.

Best For: Anyone prioritizing effectiveness, flexibility, and value.

2. Creatine Pills/Capsules: The Convenient Choice

Creatine pills or capsules (typically containing CrM) offer convenience and reliable dosing.

Category Details
Convenience Discreet, easy to carry, and require no measuring or mixing—ideal for busy lifestyles or travel. Eliminate any unpleasant taste or texture.
Dosing Fixed dosing per pill ensures consistency without manual measurement. However, reaching the standard 3-5 gram daily dose may require taking 6-10 pills (depending on capsule size), which some find cumbersome. Fixed dosing per pill ensures consistency without manual measurement. However, reaching the standard 3-5 gram daily dose may require taking more than 1 pill and the loading phase can require 6-10 pills (depending on capsule size), which some find cumbersome.
Absorption Slightly slower absorption compared to powder, as the capsule must break down first. The difference is minimal in practice.
Cost More expensive than powder due to encapsulation and packaging costs.
Side Effects Generally cause fewer digestive issues than powder, as the creatine passes into the stomach in a compact, controlled form.

Best For: People who travel frequently, dislike mixing powder, or prefer hassle-free supplementation.

3. Creatine Gummies/Chews: The Tasty but Problematic Option

Gummies and chews are marketed for their convenience and candy-like taste, but they come with significant concerns.

Category Details
Convenience & Taste Extremely portable with no mixing or preparation required. Sweet, candy-like flavor appeals to those who dislike traditional supplements.
Efficacy & Purity Major concern: While the FDA lists CrM as Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) for functional foods, independent testing reveals many brands contain little to none of the claimed creatine content. Creatine degrades rapidly when exposed to moisture and acidic environments—both inherent to gummy formulations.
Dosing Typically contain 0.5-1 gram of creatine per gummy. Reaching the recommended 3-5 gram dose requires consuming multiple gummies, significantly increasing sugar and calorie intake.
Cost Significantly more expensive than powder. Alternative creatine forms cost approximately 116% more per gram than CrM. Gummies are at the highest end of this premium.
Stability Issues Creatine’s stability in gummy form is questionable, with degradation accelerating over time. You may be paying for an ineffective product.

Best For: Those who absolutely cannot tolerate other forms—but proceed with caution and choose reputable, third-party tested brands.

Quick Format Comparison

Feature Powder Pills/Capsules Gummies/Chews
Scientific Backing Strong Evidence (Gold Standard) Strong Evidence (if proper dose achieved) Limited/Varied (purity concerns)
Cost Most Economical More Expensive Most Expensive
Convenience Requires preparation/mixing High Convenience/Discreet Highest Convenience/Portable
Dosing Precision Highly Flexible & Precise Fixed, requires multiple pills Fixed, may need excessive consumption
Digestive Tolerance Can cause bloating if poorly mixed Lower risk of digestive issues Variable; purity issues may cause problems
Absorption Speed Fast Moderate Unknown/Variable

How to Make Your Decision

Choose Powder If: You want the best value, dosing flexibility, and most research-backed option.

Choose Pills/Capsules If: Convenience and portability are your top priorities.

Choose Gummies If: You absolutely cannot tolerate other forms—but only buy from third-party tested brands due to significant purity concerns.

What to Look For When Shopping

Quality Indicators:

  • Third-party testing (NSF, Informed Choice, or USP)
  • Micronized creatine (for powder)
  • Minimal additives and transparent labeling
  • Reputable, established brands

Red Flags to Avoid:

  • Claims of dramatic superiority to monohydrate
  • Proprietary blends without disclosed amounts
  • Lack of third-party testing
  • Excessive marketing hype without science

Final Recommendation

For proven effectiveness, extensive research support, and value, creatine monohydrate powder remains the superior choice. If convenience is essential, pills/capsules offer a solid alternative. Gummies should be a last resort due to purity concerns and high cost.

Remember: the best creatine supplement is the one you’ll take consistently. Choose the format that fits your lifestyle, but prioritize quality, third-party testing, and—most importantly—creatine monohydrate as your active ingredient.

item.content:encoded:
What Exactly Is a Protein Supplement?

Protein supplements are concentrated forms of protein extracted from food sources like dairy (whey, casein), eggs, meat, or plants (pea, soy, rice, hemp). They are designed to help people increase their daily protein intake and support lean muscle mass. You’ll find protein supplements in many forms: powders, bars, and ready-to-drink shakes.

Depending on how much the protein is processed, it’s usually labeled as:

  • Concentrate: typically ~70–80% protein by weight
  • Isolate: usually 90%+ protein with fewer carbs and fats
  • Hydrolysate: partially pre-digested protein for faster absorption

Why Protein Matters (Even If You’re Not an Athlete)

Protein is essential for everyone. It helps build and maintain muscle, repair tissue after exercise or daily wear, support enzymes and hormones, and increase fullness to help manage appetite.

Most of your protein should still come from whole foods like lean meats, fish, eggs, dairy, tofu, lentils, and beans. Protein supplements are simply a convenient top‑up when it’s hard to meet your goals from food alone.

You might benefit from them if you’re:

  • An athlete or active adult looking to support muscle recovery and performance
  • Someone managing their weight who wants to stay full longer while preserving muscle
  • An older adult experiencing reduced appetite or difficulty preparing protein-rich meals
  • A busy professional who struggles to hit daily protein targets through food alone
  • A vegan or vegetarian seeking convenient plant-based protein options

Key Benefits of Protein Supplementation

Used strategically, protein supplements can help you:

  • Stimulate muscle protein synthesis (MPS)
  • Build and maintain muscle and connective tissue
  • Endurance and recovery after exercise or daily wear and tear
  • Manage appetite, weight and body composition
  • Support enzymes, hormones, and immune function

1. Stimulating Muscle Protein Synthesis (MPS)

Muscle protein synthesis (MPS) is how your body repairs and builds muscle tissue. Resistance training stimulates MPS, and consuming high-quality protein (especially sources rich in leucine, like whey) amplifies that effect.

For most people who exercise regularly, a total daily protein intake of about 1.4–2.0 g/kg body weight is sufficient to build and maintain muscle mass when combined with resistance training.

2. Build and Maintain Muscle and Connective Tissue

When you combine regular resistance training, adequate total protein intake, and consistent caloric intake, you create the ideal environment for muscle growth and strength gains. Protein supplements can make it easier to hit those daily numbers, especially around workouts or when appetite is low.

3. Endurance and Recovery after Exercise or Daily Wear and Tear

Protein isn’t just for lifters. Endurance athletes also benefit when they pair carbohydrates and protein:

Carbohydrates replenish glycogen stores, your muscles’ main fuel, while protein helps repair muscle damage and reduce soreness after long or intense sessions.

Research suggests that muscles remain more sensitive to protein intake for at least 24 hours after resistance exercise, so what matters most is hitting your daily protein target, not just pounding a shake immediately after your workout.

4. Managing Appetite, Weight and Body Composition

High‑protein diets can:

  • Help reduce fat mass while maintaining or increasing lean muscle
  • Improve satiety (you feel fuller for longer)
  • Reduce hunger and cravings, making a calorie deficit easier to sustain

When dieting, higher protein intakes (often 1.6–2.2 g/kg) can help preserve muscle during fat loss, especially when combined with strength training.

5. Supporting Enzymes, Hormones, and Immune Function

Protein isn’t just for muscles. Amino acids are the building blocks for enzymes that drive metabolic reactions, hormones that regulate everything from appetite to stress response, and antibodies that power your immune system. When protein intake falls short, these systems compete for limited resources. Adequate intake, whether from food or supplements, ensures your body can maintain these critical functions alongside muscle repair and growth.

Metabolic and Heart Health Considerations

Metabolic Support

Certain protein supplements may offer additional benefits for people with specific health concerns.

Whey protein contains the branched-chain amino acid leucine and other bioactive components that can:

  • Support insulin secretion and incretin hormones like GLP-1
  • Help moderate post-meal blood sugar responses when consumed with carbohydrates
  • Slow gastric emptying and increase feelings of fullness

These effects have been observed mostly in people with insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes. Protein supplements aren’t a replacement for diabetes medications but may be a useful tool under medical guidance.

Cardiovascular Support

Two protein sources are often discussed for heart health:

  • Whey protein: When hydrolyzed, can release small peptides that have ACE‑inhibitory properties, which may modestly lower blood pressure in some people. Effects are generally small but meta-analyses suggest slight reductions in systolic blood pressure.
  • Soy protein: Especially with isoflavones has been linked to reductions in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides in controlled trials and meta-analyses, particularly in people with high cholesterol.

These are supportive effects, not stand‑alone treatments for cardiometabolic disease.

Protein for the Aging Population

As we age, we naturally lose muscle mass and strength (sarcopenia), which can affect balance, mobility, and independence. Older adults generally benefit from higher protein intakes than the minimum Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA).

Expert groups often recommend 1.0–1.2 g/kg body weight per day for healthy older adults, and even higher (up to ~1.5 g/kg) in some cases of illness or injury, combined with regular physical activity and resistance training when possible.

Protein supplements can be especially helpful for older adults who have reduced appetite, difficulty chewing or preparing protein‑rich meals and need convenient, easy‑to‑consume options.

Protein Pacing: How to Spread Protein Through the Day

Your body can only use so much protein at once for muscle building. Many sports nutrition experts recommend spreading protein evenly across your day, known as “protein pacing”.

A simple guideline:

  • Aim for 20–40 g of high‑quality protein per meal or snack, every 3–4 hours.

Protein supplements make this easier, especially at breakfast (where protein is often low), after workouts, and during busy workdays or travel.

Safety Considerations and Potential Side Effects

For healthy individuals, protein supplementation in the ranges discussed above is generally considered safe and well-tolerated. A few things to watch for:

  • Digestive issues: Some people experience bloating, gas, or stomach discomfort, especially with dairy-based proteins like whey or casein, or if they’re lactose intolerant.
  • Acne and skin changes: A few studies have linked whey protein to increased acne in susceptible individuals, likely due to hormonal and insulin responses.
  • Allergies: Those allergic to dairy, eggs, or soy, you should avoid proteins derived from those sources and choose alternatives like pea or rice protein instead.
  • Kidney or liver disease: People with existing kidney or liver conditions must consult their healthcare provider before increasing protein intake.

Always check with your doctor or a qualified healthcare professional before starting any new supplement program, especially if you have medical conditions or take medications. Many protein supplements contain added sweeteners, flavors, gums, or other additives. Check labels to make sure the product fits your needs.

How to Use Protein Supplements Wisely

Use protein supplements to fill gaps, not to replace all your meals.

Food first: Base your diet on whole, minimally processed foods. Use supplements when it’s inconvenient or difficult to hit your protein target.

Match the protein type to your needs:

  • Whey isolate or hydrolysate: Good for fast absorption and for those who want lower lactose.
  • Casein: Slower-digesting; often used before bed.
  • Plant-based blends (e.g., pea + rice): Great for vegans, vegetarians, or those avoiding dairy.

Watch the extras: Keep an eye on sugar, artificial sweeteners, and unnecessary fillers.

Dose smartly: Think in terms of meals and totals per day, not just “How big is my shake?”

Ready to Optimize Your Protein Intake?

Not sure where to start? We can help. If you’d like to understand your personal protein requirements, design a high-protein meal plan that fits your lifestyle, or choose a supplement that aligns with your goals, book a call with one of our health coaches, and we’ll walk you through it step by step. You can read about how to choose the best protein for you here.

item.content:encoded:
What Is Creatine and Why Does It Matter?

Creatine is a naturally occurring compound composed of three amino acids: arginine, glycine, and methionine. Your body synthesizes creatine primarily in the liver and kidneys, and you can also obtain it from foods like salmon, red meat, and chicken.

However, getting enough creatine from food alone is challenging—you’d need to eat several pounds of meat daily to match what a single 5-gram supplement provides. This is why creatine monohydrate supplementation has become so popular.

How Does Creatine Work?

Creatine functions as an energy buffer for your muscles and brain. Most of the creatine in your body is stored in muscles as phosphocreatine (PCr). The enzyme creatine kinase (CK) facilitates PCr’s conversion into adenosine triphosphate (ATP)—your body’s primary energy currency. By supplementing with creatine monohydrate, you increase your body’s capacity to produce ATP, especially during high-intensity activities.

Key Benefits of Creatine Supplementation

Creatine monohydrate is one of the most extensively researched supplements available, with applications extending far beyond athletic performance. It’s safe, effective, and affordable, offering health benefits across various life stages—from enhancing strength and endurance to supporting bone density, brain function, and healthy aging.

Athletic Performance and Recovery

Creatine is well-established in the sporting community and recognized as a safe, legal performance-enhancing supplement by governing bodies like the United States Anti-Doping Agency (USADA).

Performance Benefits:

  • Increases energy production during short-burst, high-intensity anaerobic activities
  • Enhances muscular power, strength, and explosiveness (particularly in the first 10 seconds of activity)
  • When combined with carbohydrates and protein, boosts muscle glycogen stores for sustained intense exercise

Recovery Benefits:

  • Reduces muscle damage, inflammation, and soreness
  • Athletes supplementing with creatine experience fewer musculoskeletal injuries
  • When injuries do occur, recovery times are typically faster

Brain Protection: The International Society of Sports Nutrition (ISSN) recommends creatine for athletes in contact or collision sports due to its neuroprotective effects against concussions and traumatic brain injury (TBI).

Cognitive Function and Brain Health

Your brain consumes approximately 20% of your body’s total energy. Recent research shows creatine supplementation can increase brain phosphocreatine content by 5-15%, providing significant cognitive benefits.

A systematic review and meta-analysis published in Frontiers in Nutrition found that creatine supplementation positively impacts:

  • Memory retention and recall
  • Processing speed
  • Attention and focus

By increasing PCr levels and reducing oxidative stress in the brain, creatine helps you complete mental tasks more efficiently—making it valuable not just for athletes, but for students, professionals, and anyone facing cognitive demands.

Metabolic and Cardiovascular Health

Creatine offers notable benefits for metabolic and cardiovascular function:

Blood Sugar Management: Insulin and glucose influence creatine uptake into muscle tissue. When combined with exercise, creatine supplementation can significantly improve glucose management by increasing GLUT-4 (Type 4 Glucose Transporter) expression, thereby enhancing glucose uptake into skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. This leads to improved HbA1c levels—a key marker of long-term blood sugar control.

Heart Health:

  • Reduces homocysteine levels, which correlates with lower heart disease risk
  • Helps manage ischemia (reduced blood flow to organs like the heart)
  • Provides an alternative energy source when glucose or oxygen is limited, helping maintain heart function during stress

Healthy Aging, Muscle & Bone Support

Creatine helps counteract age-related decline in two critical areas:

Muscle Preservation (Sarcopenia Prevention): When combined with resistance training, creatine is particularly effective at combating sarcopenia (age-related muscle loss). Benefits include:

  • Greater lean muscle mass gains
  • Improved strength
  • Enhanced ability to perform daily tasks

Bone Health: Creatine supplementation paired with resistance training helps:

  • Mitigate bone density loss
  • Increase bone mineral content
  • Reduce fracture risk as you age

Safety Considerations and Potential Side Effects

Creatine is on the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) list and is backed by decades of research demonstrating its safety profile.

Potential Side Effects (Generally Mild):

  • Water retention: Creatine draws water into muscle cells, which may cause a small increase in body weight (2-4 lbs)
  • Digestive discomfort: Some people experience mild bloating or stomach upset, especially during the loading phase or when taking large doses on an empty stomach
  • Hydration needs: Increased water intake is important when supplementing with creatine

Dosage Recommendations and Monitoring

Phase Dosage Notes
Loading (Optional) 20 g/day (0.3 g/kg BW) for 5–7 days followed by maintainace phase Speeds up saturation of muscle stores
Maintenance 3–5 g/day (0.1 g/kg BW) Sustains elevated creatine levels
Hydration 2.5–3.5 L/day Adequate hydration enhances absorption

Making an Informed Decision About Creatine

Creatine monohydrate stands out as one of the most thoroughly researched supplements available, with hundreds of peer-reviewed studies documenting its effects. The evidence consistently shows it’s safe, affordable, and effective for a wide range of health and performance goals.

Ready to start supplementing? Learn how to choose the right creatine product in our guide: How to Choose the Best Creatine Supplement.

Summary / Key Takeaways

Creatine monohydrate is one of the most well-researched and effective supplements available. It works by increasing phosphocreatine (PCr) stores in your body, providing benefits for:

✓ Athletic performance – Enhanced strength, power, and recovery

✓ Brain function – Improved memory, focus, and processing speed

✓ Metabolic health – Better glucose management and cardiovascular support

✓ Healthy aging – Protection against muscle loss and bone density decline

Bottom Line: Whether you’re an athlete, student, professional, or simply want to support your long-term health, creatine monohydrate offers significant benefits with minimal risk. At 3-5 grams per day, it’s an affordable investment in your physical and cognitive performance.

item.content:encoded:
Have you ever taken two blood tests close together and noticed the numbers were slightly different, even though you felt like nothing had changed? You’re not imagining things: blood test results naturally vary, and understanding why can help you interpret your health data more accurately and with greater confidence.

The Reality of Laboratory Testing

Here’s something that might surprise you: if you took the exact same blood sample and tested it multiple times in the same lab, on the same day, with the same equipment, you’d still get slightly different results each time. This isn’t a sign of poor lab quality, it’s an inherent characteristic of all laboratory testing, even in the most sophisticated facilities.

Every CLIA-certified laboratory (that’s the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments certification that ensures quality standards) operates within accepted margins of variation. These margins are scientifically established and carefully monitored to ensure your results are reliable while acknowledging the reality of measurement precision.

Why Measurements Vary: Analytical Precision Limits

Even the most advanced laboratory equipment has inherent precision limits. When a lab measures your cholesterol, glucose, or any biomarker, the process involves:

  1. Sample handling: Tiny variations in how blood is collected, transported, and stored
  2. Reagent variation: The chemical substances used in testing have slight batch-to-batch differences
  3. Instrument calibration: Even calibrated instruments have precision tolerances
  4. Environmental factors: Temperature and humidity can subtly affect reactions
  5. Human factors: Technician technique, though standardized, introduces minimal variation

Each step introduces small amounts of variability that accumulate into what’s called “analytical variation” or “measurement error.”

Understanding CLIA Allowable Error Standards

The CLIA program establishes something called “Total Allowable Error” (TEa) for each biomarker—the maximum amount of variation permitted while still providing clinically useful and reliable information. These standards are rigorously defined based on:

  • The biological importance of the marker
  • The technical capabilities of available testing methods
  • The clinical decisions that depend on the results
  • Medical usefulness and necessity

Real CLIA Error Margins for Common Biomarkers

Here are the actual CLIA Total Allowable Error limits for biomarkers commonly tracked for cardiovascular and metabolic health:

Lipid Panel:

  • Total Cholesterol: ±10%
  • HDL Cholesterol: ±30%
  • Triglycerides: ±25%
  • LDL Cholesterol: ±30% (when directly measured)

Metabolic Markers:

  • Glucose: ±10% (or ±6 mg/dL, whichever is greater)
  • HbA1c: ±6%

Other Key Markers:

  • Creatinine: ±15%
  • ALT (liver enzyme): ±20%
  • TSH (thyroid): ±30%

These percentages represent the maximum acceptable deviation from the “true” value. Most high-quality labs perform well within these limits, but the standards acknowledge that some variation is inherent and acceptable.

What This Means in Practice

Let’s look at some real-world examples:

Example 1: Total Cholesterol

  • Your result: 200 mg/dL
  • CLIA allowable error: ±10%
  • Acceptable range: 180-220 mg/dL
  • If you retested immediately and got 210 mg/dL, this would be completely within expected variation

Example 2: HDL Cholesterol

  • Your result: 50 mg/dL
  • CLIA allowable error: ±30%
  • Acceptable range: 35-65 mg/dL
  • HDL has wider margins because it’s technically more challenging to measure precisely

Example 3: HbA1c

  • Your result: 5.5%
  • CLIA allowable error: ±6% of the value (that’s 0.33 percentage points)
  • Acceptable range: 5.2-5.8%
  • This marker has tighter tolerances because small changes are clinically significant

The Power of Serial Measurements

Here’s an important reality about blood testing that many people don’t realize: many biomarkers work best as serial measurements rather than single snapshots. When you establish a personal baseline through multiple tests over time, you can spot meaningful deviations much more reliably than from any single measurement.

Currently, most doctors rely on single measurements due to logistical constraints—getting patients to come in for blood draws is time-consuming and inconvenient. But this approach has a significant limitation: a single measurement of many biomarkers contains substantial uncertainty. Biomarkers can fluctuate for numerous reasons, and without a personal baseline established through repeated testing, it’s difficult to know whether a value represents your typical level or a temporary variation.

This is where regular at-home testing becomes powerful. By testing more frequently—whether monthly, quarterly, or at whatever interval makes sense for your health goals—you create a personalized reference range. You’ll know what’s normal for you, making it much easier to identify when something has genuinely changed.

Visualizing Your Error Margins

To help you better understand these natural variations in your own results, we’ve built a “See Error Bars” feature into your health reports. This tool visualizes the expected measurement variation for each of your biomarkers, based on CLIA Total Allowable Error guidelines and established analytical performance standards.

When you view your results, you can toggle this feature to see the range within which your measurement falls when accounting for analytical variation. This view helps you put your numbers in perspective and understand which changes between tests are likely to be meaningful versus those that fall within expected measurement variation. It’s like seeing your results with their natural “confidence interval”—giving you a more complete picture of your health data.

When Is a Change Actually Meaningful?

Understanding CLIA error margins helps you distinguish between measurement noise and genuine biological change. For a change between two tests to be considered truly significant (meaning it likely represents a real change in your biology rather than measurement variation), it generally needs to exceed the combined error margins of both tests.

The Importance of Patterns and Frequent Testing

This is where frequent testing becomes invaluable. A single change that falls near the boundary of measurement variation could be uncertain—but when you see the same directional change across two, three, or more consecutive tests, the likelihood that it represents a real biological shift increases dramatically.

Think of it this way:

  • One test showing change: Could be measurement variation or a genuine shift—uncertain
  • Two consecutive tests showing the same directional change: More likely to be real, especially if the change exceeds error margins
  • Three or more tests showing a consistent trend: Very likely represents a meaningful biological change

This is why establishing a testing routine matters. Regular testing doesn’t just track your health—it helps you distinguish signal from noise with far greater confidence.

The key insight: changes need to be substantially larger than the error margin to be considered definitively meaningful from a single retest, but patterns across multiple tests provide much stronger evidence of real change, even when individual changes are modest.

Practical Implications for Tracking Your Health

Understanding test variability empowers you to:

  1. Test regularly to establish your baseline: The more data points you have, the better you understand your personal normal ranges and can spot meaningful deviations.
  2. Look for patterns, not just single changes: A consistent trend across multiple tests is far more meaningful than any single result or comparison between just two tests.
  3. Use error margins to evaluate changes: When you see a change, compare it to the CLIA error margin (visible in your report) to understand whether it’s within expected variation or potentially meaningful.
  4. Optimize testing conditions: Try to keep testing conditions similar (time of day, fasting status, recent exercise) to minimize additional sources of variation when tracking changes.
  5. Understand your ranges in context: Results are best interpreted with their natural variation in mind. A value near the edge of a range, when viewed with its error margin, might actually overlap with multiple categories.
  6. Use consistent testing: When tracking over time, using the same laboratory helps minimize additional variation from different testing methods and equipment.

The Bottom Line

Blood testing is incredibly valuable for monitoring health, and understanding its inherent variability makes you a more informed interpreter of your own data. The CLIA standards that govern laboratory testing aren’t limitations—they’re realistic acknowledgments of the precision achievable when measuring complex biological systems.

The real power of health tracking comes from serial measurements over time. While traditional healthcare often relies on single snapshots due to logistical constraints, regular at-home testing allows you to build a personal baseline and identify meaningful changes with much greater confidence. Our error margin visualization feature puts CLIA standards to work for you, helping you see your results with appropriate context and distinguish measurement variation from genuine biological changes—especially when viewed as patterns across multiple tests.

When you notice a change, you can quickly assess whether it exceeds the expected measurement variation and, more importantly, whether it represents a consistent pattern. This is how you turn data into actionable health insights: understanding both the precision limits of individual measurements and the power of tracking trends over time.

Note: This article is for educational purposes. Always discuss your individual test results and their interpretation with qualified healthcare providers who know your complete health history.

item.content:encoded:
Blood tests don’t just measure single values: sometimes the ratio between two biomarkers can provide important insights. A ratio biomarker is simply one lab value divided by another, but this simple calculation can amplify subtle imbalances and reveal health patterns that individual numbers alone might miss. In this article, we’ll explain why these ratios are important, when they add (or don’t add) clinical value, and go through key examples. We’ll also touch on other calculated markers in lab reports and why they’re used.

Why Are Ratios Important?

Ratios can capture the balance between related biomarkers, often reflecting underlying physiology better than either number by itself. Many medical conditions are characterized by an imbalance between two measures rather than an absolute high or low in one. By comparing two related values, ratios can highlight these imbalances:

  • A ratio can sometimes serve as a surrogate marker for complex processes. The triglyceride-to-HDL cholesterol ratio (TG:HDL) is one well-known example. A high TG:HDL ratio suggests a pattern of abnormal lipid metabolism and insulin resistance. Studies have found TG:HDL to be a simple but effective indicator of insulin resistance and cardiometabolic risk, even more so than either triglycerides or HDL alone.
  • Ratios often represent the balance of “good” vs “bad” factors. In cardiovascular medicine, the ratio of apolipoprotein B to apolipoprotein A1 (ApoB/ApoA1) is a powerful predictor of heart disease risk. ApoB is the protein on “bad” cholesterol particles (LDL, VLDL, etc.), while ApoA1 is on “good” HDL particles. The ApoB:ApoA1 ratio thus indicates the balance between atherogenic (plaque-forming) and protective cholesterol in the blood. Research has shown that even if standard cholesterol levels are normal, a higher ApoB/ApoA1 ratio correlates with more severe artery disease and a higher risk of heart attack.

Ratios are important because they provide context. They can flag a risk or abnormality only evident when comparing two values. Clinicians often use ratio markers to get a more nuanced view of metabolism, organ function, or disease risk.

Limitations of Ratio Markers – When They Don’t Add Insight

Despite their value, not every ratio is clinically useful in every situation. In many cases, if both of the individual biomarkers are in a healthy, normal range, then their ratio will also fall in a normal range and does not provide additional insight. In other words, a ratio is most informative when one or both components are abnormal or at least near the edges of normal.

Because of this, labs and clinicians often don’t bother reporting or emphasizing a ratio if both constituent values are normal. In fact, experts note that it’s hard to even define a “healthy” reference range for some ratios, precisely because these ratios are mainly used to interpret abnormal results.

This is why your report will gray out certain ratios when both biomarkers are in the healthy range as this does not provide any additional clinical insight. The bottom line: ratios are most meaningful when something is off-balance in the first place.

It’s also worth noting that some ratios are only broadly useful and not definitive on their own. A ratio outside the ideal range often points to a potential issue but usually needs to be interpreted alongside the individual values and clinical context.

Below, we’ll go through specific ratio markers, explaining what they mean, why they’re measured, and how they’re interpreted (including their limitations). We’ll also mention some calculated non-ratio markers that are derived from formulas.

Examples of Important Ratio Biomarkers

AST:ALT (De Ritis) Ratio – Liver Health Indicator

What it is: The AST:ALT ratio compares two liver enzymes: aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Both AST and ALT leak into the blood when liver cells are damaged, but they can rise in different patterns depending on the cause of liver injury.

Why it’s useful: The AST:ALT ratio helps differentiate types of liver disease and the severity of liver damage. In healthy individuals, AST and ALT levels are usually similar, yielding a ratio around 1.0. But in liver disease, their proportions change. Typically, an AST/ALT > 2 (AST is more than twice ALT) is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease or alcoholic hepatitis. On the other hand, AST/ALT < 1 (ALT higher than AST) is often seen in acute viral hepatitis or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease – conditions where ALT tends to rise more prominently.

Limitations: As mentioned earlier, if AST and ALT are normal, the ratio ~1 doesn’t tell much. It’s also not a perfect test – many patients with alcoholic liver disease might not have the “textbook” >2 ratio, and other conditions can sometimes elevate AST more than ALT. The ratio should be interpreted carefully: a very high AST:ALT ratio could even be due to muscle injury (since AST is found in muscles too) or vitamin B6 deficiency affecting ALT levels.

TSH:T4 Ratio – Thyroid Function Insight

What it is: This ratio compares thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) to thyroxine (T4). TSH is the pituitary hormone that signals the thyroid gland, and free T4 is the main hormone produced by the thyroid. Normally, they have an inverse relationship: if T4 is low, TSH goes up (to stimulate the thyroid), and if T4 is high, TSH drops.

Why it’s useful: In certain situations, looking at the TSH:T4 balance can refine assessment of thyroid function. One particular use is in identifying subclinical hypothyroidism – a mild underactive thyroid state where T4 is still in the normal range but TSH is slightly elevated. In subclinical hypothyroidism, the TSH:T4 ratio will be higher than normal (because T4 is relatively low for that person’s TSH level). In fact, one study introduced a “subclinical hypothyroid index” defined by the TSH:FT4 ratio, and found it helpful for diagnosing early thyroid underactivity.

Limitations: If TSH and T4 are both well within their normal ranges, the ratio doesn’t carry much independent meaning. Also, there isn’t a universally agreed “normal” range for TSH:T4 ratio in practice – doctors interpret it relative to the context. Large variations in binding proteins or acute illness can also alter free T4 levels and thus the ratio.

Free T3:Free T4 Ratio – Thyroid Hormone Conversion

What it is: This is the ratio of free triiodothyronine (FT3) to free thyroxine (FT4). T4 is converted in the body to T3, the more active thyroid hormone. So this ratio essentially measures how much T3 activity you have relative to your T4 level.

Why it’s useful: The FT3:FT4 ratio is an indicator of T4-to-T3 conversion efficiency and overall thyroid hormone balance at the tissue level. Some patients can have normal T4 but low T3 (for example, in “low T3 syndrome” during chronic illness, or in some hypothyroid patients on T4-only therapy). A reduced FT3:FT4 ratio in such cases might suggest that tissues are not adequately converting T4 to T3. On the flip side, an abnormally high T3 relative to T4 could occur in certain thyroid disorders (like T3 toxicosis or Graves’ disease with dominant T3 secretion).

Limitations: The FT3:FT4 ratio can be influenced by factors like medications, acute illness, and age. There’s no strict normal range for the ratio used in routine practice – it’s evaluated in context. If both FT3 and FT4 are normal and the person is well, the ratio is usually in a normal middle zone and not particularly scrutinized.

Cortisol to DHEA-S Ratio – Stress and Adrenal Balance

What it is: This ratio compares cortisol (the body’s main stress hormone) to DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, an adrenal hormone that can counterbalance some effects of cortisol). Both are produced by the adrenal glands. Cortisol is catabolic (breaks down tissue, increases blood sugar, suppresses immune function), whereas DHEA and its sulfate form are anabolic and supportive of immune function.

Why it’s useful: The cortisol:DHEA-S ratio is considered a marker of HPA axis balance and stress. In a healthy young person, cortisol and DHEA levels are in good proportion, especially since DHEA-S is high in youth. With aging or chronic stress, DHEA-S levels decline significantly (by age 70, DHEA-S may be only 10–20% of young adult levels) while cortisol levels do not drop as much. The result is a higher cortisol-to-DHEA ratio, indicating a shift toward catabolic, stress-related physiology.

Moreover, studies in different fields have found that higher cortisol:DHEA ratios correlate with worse outcomes in contexts like chronic pain, depression, and critical illness. A review on pain and aging noted that an elevated cortisol-to-DHEA ratio (along with low DHEA) is associated with increased frailty, poorer immune function, osteoporosis progression, and even cognitive decline.

Limitations: There is natural variability in cortisol (which follows a diurnal rhythm) and DHEA-S (which also declines with age), so the ratio’s interpretation must consider age, time of day, and individual baseline. There’s not a single “normal range” used universally for cortisol:DHEA-S ratio; instead, one looks at whether it’s higher or lower than expected for a given context. Also, both values need to be abnormal or shifting for the ratio to be meaningful. If cortisol and DHEA-S are both normal, their ratio will usually be in a reasonable range.

What About Other Calculated Markers?

In addition to ratios, many blood test results are derived calculations rather than direct measurements. These are still valuable pieces of information in your report. Here are a few examples:

  • Calculated VLDL Cholesterol:Very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (VLDL-C) is usually not measured directly. Instead, it is estimated from triglycerides, most commonly using the Friedewald equation (VLDL ≈ triglycerides ÷ 5, in mg/dL). This calculation is also used to derive LDL cholesterol (LDL = Total Cholesterol − HDL − VLDL). Calculated VLDL is useful for completing the lipid profile and estimating cardiovascular risk, but it becomes unreliable when triglycerides are very high or when samples are non-fasting. In those cases, calculated values may be suppressed or interpreted cautiously.
  • Iron Saturation and Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC):Iron saturation and TIBC are calculated using serum iron and unsaturated iron-binding capacity (UIBC). These calculations assume that UIBC is within a physiologically meaningful range. When UIBC is very low (< 25 µg/dL), the assumptions behind these calculations break down, and TIBC and iron saturation may become misleading. For this reason, if UIBC is below this threshold, TIBC and iron saturation are not reported, and interpretation focuses instead on the directly measured values.
  • Free Androgen Index (FAI):The Free Androgen Index is a calculated marker derived from total testosterone and sex hormone–binding globulin (SHBG). It is intended as a rough estimate of androgen availability, primarily in specific clinical contexts. However, the calculation becomes unreliable when its inputs fall outside valid ranges. If SHBG is very low (< 9 nmol/L) or if total testosterone is extremely low or high (< 25.96 ng/dL or > 2018.8 ng/dL), the FAI calculation is not physiologically meaningful. In these cases, FAI is suppressed to avoid generating misleading results.
  • Free Testosterone (Calculated):Calculated free testosterone is derived from total testosterone, SHBG, and albumin using established equations (such as the Vermeulen method). While calculated free testosterone generally correlates well with reference methods, it shares the same fundamental limitation as FAI: it is only as reliable as its inputs. When SHBG or total testosterone values fall outside physiologically valid ranges, the calculation can produce distorted or non-interpretable results.

The reason calculated markers are used at all is to extract additional insight without requiring extra tests, but they are not universally applicable. When the assumptions behind a calculation are violated, reporting the value can create confusion rather than clarity. Suppressing calculated markers in those situations helps ensure that reported results remain clinically meaningful and appropriately interpreted.

Key Takeaways

  • Ratio biomarkers distill complex information from two related lab tests. They can be as clinically significant as the individual biomarkers by highlighting imbalances (e.g. cholesterol balance, liver enzyme patterns, thyroid feedback, stress hormones).
  • If both components are normal, the ratio will typically be normal too, and generally doesn’t add new clinical insight. This is why our system (and many clinicians) will not flag or focus on a ratio in that scenario. It avoids confusion and over-interpretation.
  • Ratios become important when one or both values are out of range. At that point, the ratio can help determine why and what to suspect: e.g. a high AST:ALT ratio points to a particular cause of liver injury, a high TSH:T4 ratio points to emerging hypothyroidism, etc. We automatically display these calculated ratios in such cases to give you and your healthcare provider extra context.
  • Always interpret ratios in context. A ratio out of range warrants a look at its constituents: Are one or both of the underlying labs high or low? Does that fit the person’s symptoms or risk factors? The ratio is a clue, not a diagnosis.

By understanding ratio biomarkers and calculated markers, you can better appreciate what your blood test report is conveying. These derived numbers are there to enhance understanding of your health, highlighting meaningful patterns or confirming that things are well-balanced. We hope this helps you make sense of why certain ratios show up on your report only under certain conditions.

Note: This article is for educational purposes. Always discuss your individual test results and their interpretation with qualified healthcare providers who know your complete health history.

item.content:encoded:
What is the Cortisol:DHEA-S Ratio?

Your adrenal glands sit atop your kidneys and serve as powerful regulators of your body’s stress response. Two of the most important hormones they produce are cortisol, your primary stress hormone, and DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate), an anabolic hormone that helps build resilience. The cortisol:DHEA-S ratio provides a critical lens into how your body balances breakdown and repair.

Why This Ratio Matters

Both cortisol and DHEA-S play essential roles, but they operate in opposite directions:

  • Cortisol is catabolic, breaking down tissue for immediate energy during stress.
  • DHEA-S is anabolic, supporting tissue repair, immune function, and mood stability.

Maintaining balance between the two is key. When cortisol is consistently high and DHEA-S declines (as it does with age or chronic stress), the cortisol:DHEA-S ratio increases, tipping the body toward a catabolic, inflammation-prone state. This imbalance is associated with fatigue, poor recovery, mood issues, immune dysfunction, and even premature aging.

How the Ratio Is Measured

The cortisol:DHEA-S ratio is calculated by dividing your morning fasting cortisol (measured in µg/dL) by serum DHEA-S (also in µg/dL). Because DHEA-S has a stable daily rhythm and cortisol peaks in the morning, early morning blood draws offer the most consistent results.

Example:

If your cortisol is 8 µg/dL and DHEA-S is 160 µg/dL, your ratio is 0.05.

What Does a Healthy Cortisol:DHEA-S Ratio Look Like?

The following interpretation ranges are based on research in healthy adult populations and linked to physiological aging and stress adaptation:

  • Optimal (0.03–0.07): Strong anabolic dominance, robust stress resilience
  • Good (0.07–0.10): Healthy adrenal balance in mid-life
  • Fair (0.10–0.14): Declining DHEA-S or elevated cortisol; early signs of stress load
  • Pay Attention: >0.14 (high cortisol dominance) or <0.02 (possible adrenal suppression or excessive DHEA-S)

 

Why These Cutoffs Matter

  • Ratios above 0.14 have been associated with increased risk of sarcopenia, metabolic syndrome, and immune dysfunction.
  • Ratios below 0.02, while rare, may reflect suppressed cortisol or excessive DHEA-S (e.g., from supplementation).

The Science Behind the Ratio

Aging and Hormonal Shift

DHEA-S levels peak in your 20s and decline by over 80% by your 70s, while cortisol stays relatively constant. This causes the cortisol:DHEA-S ratio to increase naturally with age, contributing to a more catabolic internal environment.

Chronic Stress and Burnout

Studies show that individuals with chronic stress or PTSD often have elevated cortisol:DHEA-S ratios. A high ratio indicates the body is prioritizing short-term survival over long-term repair. Over time, this can lead to inflammation, reduced immunity, and cognitive decline.

Metabolic and Immune Implications

Elevated cortisol:DHEA-S has been linked to:

  • Increased insulin resistance
  • Abdominal fat accumulation
  • Higher blood pressure
  • Reduced muscle mass and strength
  • Lower immune cell activity

How to Improve Your Cortisol:DHEA-S Ratio

Improving your ratio means lowering excessive cortisol or raising low DHEA-S, ideally both. Here are evidence-backed strategies:

1. Manage Stress Effectively

  • Meditation, breathwork, and yoga have been shown to reduce cortisol levels.
  • Short mindfulness sessions (10–15 min/day) can make a measurable difference.

2. Optimize Your Sleep

  • Prioritize 7–9 hours of high-quality sleep.
  • Poor sleep increases cortisol and decreases DHEA-S.
  • Stick to consistent sleep/wake times and reduce blue light exposure at night.

3. Exercise Smart

  • Moderate-intensity exercise (e.g., walking, cycling) supports hormonal balance.
  • Excessive high-intensity training can elevate cortisol long-term. Recovery is key.

4. Nutrition for Hormonal Health

  • Eat balanced meals with adequate protein, healthy fats, and complex carbs.
  • Include nutrients that support adrenal health: vitamin C, magnesium, zinc, and B vitamins.
  • Avoid frequent spikes in blood sugar and limit stimulants like caffeine.

5. Consider Adaptogens (With Medical Supervision)

  • Ashwagandha and rhodiola have been shown to modulate cortisol responses.
  • DHEA supplementation may be appropriate for some individuals under professional guidance, especially in cases of low DHEA-S.

Why This Ratio Deserves Your Attention

The cortisol:DHEA-S ratio is a powerful reflection of how your body is navigating the demands of modern life. High cortisol paired with low DHEA-S tips the scale toward inflammation, aging, and burnout. A low ratio, on the other hand, supports resilience, muscle preservation, and immune function.

Where can I learn more?

  • PubMed – Cortisol, DHEA sulphate, their ratio
  • Biogerontology – Cortisol, DHEAS, and the cortisol/DHEAS ratio as predictors of epigenetic age acceleration

Not everyone has time for a live call—but everyone deserves personalized health guidance.

You’ve invested in understanding your body through comprehensive biomarker testing. Now you need clear, actionable guidance to improve your health. But between work, family, and life, finding time for appointments can be challenging.

That’s why Siphox offers Expert Written Health Plans: personalized, written health coaching delivered on your schedule. For just $39, complete a detailed questionnaire and receive a comprehensive written action plan from a qualified health specialist, no appointment necessary.

How It Works: Simple, Flexible, Expert

Step 1: Complete Your Health Questionnaire (2-5 minutes) Answer detailed questions about:

  • Your current lifestyle (diet, exercise, sleep, stress)
  • Health goals and priorities
  • Medical history and current symptoms
  • Supplements and medications
  • Specific concerns about your biomarkers

Step 2: Expert Analysis (Behind the Scenes) A qualified health coach reviews your biomarkers alongside your questionnaire responses, analyzing patterns and identifying opportunities for optimization.

Step 3: Receive Your Personalized Action Plan (Within 3-5 business days) Get a comprehensive written plan including:

  • Summary of your biomarker analysis
  • Key findings and areas of focus
  • Specific, prioritized action items
  • Lifestyle recommendations tailored to your situation
  • Supplement suggestions with dosing guidance
  • Timeline for reassessment

Why Choose Expert Written Health Plans?

Convenience and Flexibility Complete your questionnaire whenever it works for you; early morning, lunch break, or late at night. No scheduling conflicts, no appointment anxiety.

Thorough Analysis Your coach has time to deeply analyze your biomarkers and questionnaire responses without the constraints of a live call, often resulting in more comprehensive recommendations.

Written Documentation Everything is documented in writing from the start. You can reference your action plan anytime, share it with your doctor, and track your progress over time without relying on notes from a call.

Perfect for Introverts Not everyone wants to jump on a call. Some people process information better in writing and prefer the privacy of a written exchange.

International Friendly No matter where you are in the world, no matter your time zone, you can access expert health coaching without coordination challenges.

Time to Reflect Review your action plan carefully, research recommendations, and formulate follow-up questions without the pressure of a live conversation.

What’s Included in Your Action Plan

Your comprehensive written action plan covers:

Biomarker Summary

  • Overview of your key results
  • Explanation of what each marker means
  • Context for your specific situation

Lifestyle Analysis

  • Assessment of your current diet, exercise, sleep, and stress management
  • Identification of gaps and opportunities

Prioritized Action Items

  • Specific, actionable recommendations ranked by impact
  • Clear instructions for implementation
  • Expected timeline for each intervention

Supplementation Guidance

  • Which supplements to consider and why
  • Specific dosing recommendations
  • Timing and combination guidance

Next Steps

  • When to retest biomarkers
  • What to monitor for improvement
  • How to track progress

The Science Behind Written Coaching

Research shows that written action plans increase adherence to health interventions by providing:

Clarity: Written recommendations eliminate misunderstanding or forgotten details from verbal conversations

Commitment: Writing down goals and actions increases the likelihood of follow-through

Reference: You can review your plan whenever you need motivation or clarity

Accountability: Having a documented plan makes it easier to track what you’ve implemented and what still needs attention

Common Areas Addressed in Action Plans

Based on your biomarkers and questionnaire, your action plan may include guidance on:

  • Metabolic Optimization: Blood sugar control, insulin sensitivity, lipid management
  • Hormonal Balance: Thyroid support, sex hormone optimization, cortisol regulation
  • Cardiovascular Health: Cholesterol improvement, blood pressure management, inflammation reduction
  • Dietary Strategy: Meal composition, macronutrient ratios, food timing, specific foods to emphasize or avoid
  • Exercise Prescription: Type, intensity, frequency, and timing of workouts
  • Sleep Enhancement: Duration, quality, sleep hygiene, circadian rhythm optimization
  • Stress Reduction: Practical techniques for managing chronic stress
  • Targeted Supplementation: Evidence-based supplement recommendations specific to your deficiencies

Is This Right for You?

Expert Written Health Plans are ideal if you:

✓ Prefer written communication over live calls

✓ Want to complete your health assessment on your own schedule

✓ Value having detailed documentation to reference

✓ Like to process information thoroughly before asking questions

✓ Live in a different time zone or have an unpredictable schedule

✓ Want comprehensive analysis without time pressure

✓ Prefer privacy and written records

✓ Need to share recommendations with your doctor

Get Your Personalized Action Plan: Just $39

For the price of a supplement bottle, you can receive expert guidance tailored specifically to your biomarkers and lifestyle.

What you get for $39:

  • Detailed health questionnaire to capture your complete picture
  • Expert analysis from a qualified health coach
  • Comprehensive written action plan with 5-10 prioritized recommendations
  • Supplement guidance with specific dosing
  • Timeline for reassessment

item.content:encoded:
What is Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)?

Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) is a calculated value derived from your HbA1c (hemoglobin A1c) test results. While HbA1c is reported as a percentage, eAG translates that percentage into the same units used by home blood glucose meters: milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or millimoles per liter (mmol/L). This conversion makes it easier for people to understand their long-term blood sugar control in relation to the numbers they see during daily glucose monitoring. The formula used to calculate eAG was established by the A1c-Derived Average Glucose (ADAG) study, which included 507 subjects from 10 international centers: eAG (mg/dL) = (28.7 x A1C) – 46.7.

Why is Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) important?

Tracking your eAG helps you understand your average blood sugar levels over the past two to three months, providing valuable insight into how well your diabetes management plan is working. Unlike a single fasting glucose test, eAG reflects glucose levels throughout the day, including after meals and overnight. This comprehensive view makes eAG a useful tool for both patients and healthcare providers when assessing glycemic control.

High eAG values indicate chronically elevated blood sugar, which increases the risk of diabetes complications such as cardiovascular disease, kidney damage (nephropathy), nerve damage (neuropathy), and eye problems (retinopathy). Symptoms of consistently high blood sugar may include increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision, and slow-healing wounds. Low eAG values in people with diabetes may indicate well-controlled blood sugar, but excessively low values could suggest frequent hypoglycemic episodes, which can be dangerous and may cause confusion, shakiness, sweating, and in severe cases, loss of consciousness. If you are concerned about your eAG levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) levels?

According to the American Diabetes Association and MedlinePlus:

  • Normal (non-diabetic): 70-126 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C of 4-6%)
  • Prediabetes range: 117-137 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C of 5.7-6.4%)
  • Diabetes target for most adults: <154 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C <7%)
  • Diabetes diagnosis threshold: >140 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C >6.5%)

Common A1C to eAG conversions:

  • A1C 5%: eAG 97 mg/dL
  • A1C 6%: eAG 126 mg/dL
  • A1C 7%: eAG 154 mg/dL
  • A1C 8%: eAG 183 mg/dL
  • A1C 9%: eAG 212 mg/dL
  • A1C 10%: eAG 240 mg/dL

It is important to note that your eAG may not match the average of your home glucose meter readings. This is because most people tend to check their blood sugar before meals or when they feel low, which does not capture post-meal spikes or overnight glucose levels. eAG provides a more complete picture of your 24-hour glucose exposure.

Certain conditions and medications can affect the accuracy of eAG calculations, including anemia, kidney disease, sickle cell disease, thalassemia, and recent blood transfusions. If you have any of these conditions, discuss with your healthcare provider how to best interpret your results.

How can I maintain optimal eAG levels?

If you need to maintain or improve your eAG levels, consider the following strategies:

Dietary Changes: Focus on a balanced diet rich in fiber from vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. Limit refined carbohydrates, sugary beverages, and ultra-processed foods. The American Diabetes Association recommends following the Diabetes Plate Method: fill half your plate with non-starchy vegetables, one quarter with lean protein, and one quarter with whole grains or starchy foods. Pairing carbohydrates with protein, fiber, and healthy fats can help prevent blood sugar spikes.

Physical Activity: Regular exercise improves insulin sensitivity and helps your body use glucose more efficiently. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week, such as brisk walking, swimming, or cycling. Incorporating two to three sessions of resistance training weekly can further improve blood sugar control. Physical activity can lower blood glucose for up to 24 hours after your workout.

Lifestyle Changes: Managing stress through meditation, yoga, or deep breathing exercises can help lower blood sugar, as stress hormones cause glucose levels to rise. Prioritize quality sleep of seven to nine hours per night, as poor sleep negatively impacts blood sugar regulation. If you smoke, quitting can significantly improve your diabetes management and reduce the risk of complications.

Medication Adherence: If your healthcare provider has prescribed diabetes medications or insulin, take them exactly as directed. Missing doses can lead to blood sugar fluctuations that will raise your eAG over time. Discuss any concerns about side effects or costs with your doctor before making changes.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)
  • American Diabetes Association – A1C and eAG Conversion Calculator
  • Diabetes Care – Translating the A1C Assay Into Estimated Average Glucose Values (Nathan et al., 2008)
  • National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program – HbA1c and eAG

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your eAG results and for personalized diabetes management recommendations.

item.content:encoded:
What is % free testosterone?

Testosterone circulates in the blood in three forms: tightly bound to sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), weakly bound to albumin, and unbound (free). Percent free testosterone (% free testosterone) is a calculated value that represents the ratio of free testosterone to total testosterone in your blood. While free testosterone typically accounts for only 1-3% of total testosterone in men and less than 1% in women, this small fraction is critically important because it represents the biologically active form of the hormone that can readily enter cells and exert its effects.

Why is % free testosterone important?

Tracking your % free testosterone provides valuable insight into how much testosterone is actually available for your body to use, beyond what a total testosterone test alone can reveal. This measurement is particularly useful when total testosterone levels appear normal but symptoms of testosterone deficiency persist. Because of its clinical significance, % free testosterone may be included in comprehensive hormone panels offered by SiPhox Health.

A low % free testosterone may indicate that too much testosterone is bound to SHBG, leaving insufficient active hormone available to tissues. This can occur even when total testosterone is within normal range. Conditions associated with elevated SHBG include hyperthyroidism, liver disease, and aging. Symptoms of low bioavailable testosterone may include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, fatigue, depression, reduced muscle mass, and decreased bone density. A high % free testosterone may indicate low SHBG levels, which can be seen in obesity, insulin resistance, hypothyroidism, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in women. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my % free testosterone levels?

Adult Males:

  • Low: <1.0%
  • Normal: 1.0-2.7%
  • Optimal: 2.0-3.0%
  • High: >3.0%

Adult Females:

  • Low: <0.3%
  • Normal: 0.3-1.0%
  • High: >1.0%

Percent free testosterone is typically calculated using measurements of total testosterone, SHBG, and albumin through validated formulas such as the Vermeulen equation. This calculation provides a reliable estimate of free testosterone without requiring the more complex and expensive direct measurement methods like equilibrium dialysis.

It is important to interpret % free testosterone in conjunction with total testosterone and SHBG levels for a complete picture of hormonal status. Testing should be performed in the morning (between 8-10 a.m.) when testosterone levels are highest. As SHBG tends to increase with age, the % free testosterone often becomes a more reliable indicator of testosterone availability than total testosterone in older individuals.

How can I maintain optimal % free testosterone levels?

If you need to maintain or adjust your % free testosterone levels, consider the following strategies:

Exercise: Resistance training and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) have been shown to support healthy testosterone levels. Regular physical activity can also help optimize body composition, which influences SHBG levels.

Weight Management: Maintaining a healthy body weight is crucial, as obesity is associated with lower SHBG and altered testosterone metabolism. Weight loss in overweight individuals can help normalize hormone balance.

Nutrition: Ensure adequate intake of zinc, vitamin D, and magnesium, which support testosterone production. Protein intake influences SHBG levels, and a balanced diet with adequate healthy fats supports overall hormone health.

Lifestyle: Prioritize 7-9 hours of quality sleep per night, as sleep deprivation negatively impacts testosterone production. Manage stress levels, as chronic stress elevates cortisol which can affect testosterone. Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Testosterone Levels Test
  • MedlinePlus – SHBG Blood Test
  • Cleveland Clinic – Testosterone Test
  • NIH PMC – Reference Ranges for Testosterone in Men (Framingham Heart Study)
